intro: Dianthus glaucophyllus, commonly known as the glaucous pinks, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is characterized by its compact, evergreen foliage and showy, pink or white flowers that bloom in spring. The plant typically grows to a height of about 15–30 centimeters and prefers well-drained, sandy soils. It is often cultivated as an ornamental plant for its attractive appearance and ability to thrive in rocky or arid conditions. Dianthus glaucophyllus is also valued for its drought tolerance and low maintenance requirements.
